title: An asteroid is heading towards the Earth. What is the quantity of the asteroid that would change as it came closer to the Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: I take ‘quantity’ to mean any measurable value directly associated with the asteroid. It would increase in brightness as it neared the Earth, because it would be reflecting sunlight more efficiently, from our point of view. It’s orbit would be changed slightly by its interaction with Earth’s gravity. It’s velocity relative to Earth could increase, for the same reason.

There is no reason for the object to change at all. Now if you were talking about an object coming from deep space, like the Kuiper belt or the Oort Cloud, then it could have icy material that would sublimate and boil off as it gets closer to the Sun, because the intensity of sunlight is inversely proportional to the square of the object’s distance from the Sun. This has nothing to do with the Earth.

It’s mass would remain, but its weight would increase as the gravitational field enveloped it. We would not notice it unless it stopped here, when kinetic energy was released. On the way, ke is increasing, and weight as a result of momentum. The point is that the mass might be movable, and the asteroid be “steered” or deflected as long as it just happened to be heading towards Earth, but it gets much harder once it’s attracted by our gravity. If it only skims the atmosphere (a bolide), it will lose mass and weight if it fragments, or may gain mass by oxidation if it does not.
I assume you mean as it hits the Earth’s atmosphere? So it would depend on the size of the asteroid, how much atmosphere it hits and how this affects mass and velocity.
